contents.context:
U.S. President Trump announced on Sunday that he will be withdrawing the National Guard from Washington D.C., after a weekend of peaceful protests.
CNN reported that around five thousand National Guard troops had been called to patrol Washington D.C.
Trump didn't clearly say if all National Guard forces have been withdrawn, but the Secretary of the Army Ryan McCarthy said that out-of-state Guard forces, which makeup the majority of those deployed in the capital, started going home on Sunday.
Meanwhile, the protests against racism and police brutality that began in the U.S. are spreading around the globe.

"We need to bring it domestically, we need to remember that the UK is not innocent, everything you see around you is built off the backs of black and brown bodies."

At a protest in Bristol, people tore down a statue of slave trader Edward Colston and threw it into Bristol Harbour.
Amid reports of several injuries to police officers in the UK protests, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that while people have the right to protest, they have no right to attack the police.
Demonstrators also gathered in Liberty Square in Budapest on Sunday and knelt in silence for eight minutes and 46 seconds the length of time Floyd was lying on the ground with a police officer's knee pressed down on his neck.

"It is really sad what is happening in America and I am glad that we are all taking a stand all over the world because enough is enough."

Protests against racism also took place in Spain, Italy, Germany and other countries over the weekend.
Jang Tae-hyun, Arirang News
Reporter : tommyjang@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Trump withdraws National Guard from Washington D.C.; Europe sees Black Lives Matter protests over weekend
Updated: 2020-06-08 17:09:10 KST

contents.context:
New Zealand announced Monday that it has halted the spread of COVID-19, reporting no new cases of the coronavirus for 17 consecutive days.
With zero active cases, the country is scrapping its social distancing requirements effective Monday midnight.

That means schools and businesses will re-open, and there will be no restrictions on domestic travel, public gatherings or sporting events.
People will only be asked to keep track of where they’ve been to help in contact tracing if future cases emerge.

Prime minister Jacinda Ardern attributed New Zealand's success to its strict border controls.

"The reason that New Zealanders, as of tomorrow, will be able to move around with freedom that very few other countries in the world have is because we are maintaining those restrictions at the border."

New Zealand became the 48th country to confirm a case of COVID-19 on February 28th.
When it had just six cases, the government ordered anyone entering the country to self-quarantine for two weeks,which at the time was among the toughest border restrictions in the world.
Then the country closed its borders to all foreigners.
When the number of cases had risen to a hundred, but still with no deaths, New Zealand shut down all non-essential businesses, events and gatherings, and closed its schools.
Two days later, the government raised the lockdown to level 4, the highest level, requiring people to stay home except for essential activities.
Despite a decline in cases, it tightened the border further, requiring even New Zealand citizens arriving in the country to spend their first two weeks quarantined not at home but at an approved facility.

New Zealand's borders remain shut to non-residents, and residents who do arrive still have to quarantine for two weeks.
But social distancing, while still encouraged, is no longer required.
Choi Jeong-yoon, Arirang News.
Reporter : jychoi@arirang.com
contents.headline:
New Zealand reports 'zero' active COVID-19 cases
Updated: 2020-06-08 17:09:02 KST

contents.context:
One month since the nation eased its strict social distancing measures to 'distancing in daily lives' and nearly six months since the first case of COVID-19 in the country, South Korea's new virus cases slowed to high 30s today after reporting more than 50 cases for two straight days.
Nonetheless, concerns are running high over a possible second wave of the pandemic in the greater Seoul area as we continue to witness cases with no clear epidemiological links and as our last group of children went back to the classrooms in the final phase of the country's school reopening plan.
Life with COVID-19, it's the topic of our News In-depth with our favorite medical expert, Dr. Alice Tan live in the studio with us tonight.
Alice, thanks for being back on our show.

It's already been half a year since we've first encountered this coronavirus. The season has changed from winter to summer.
After seeing the first case of the coronavirus in January, we saw COVID-19 spike to as high as 850 a day flattened to as low as single digit new cases daily. But, in recent weeks, we've again seen that number back up in the high 30s, 40s and 50s. It appears that's the nature of this virus. As soon as we think we may be seeing the end of it; as soon as we let our guards down, or loosen our vigilance a little bit, a cluster infection breaks out somewhere. What do we do?

We are beginning to see temperatures rise across the nation. In fact, the first heatwave advisory of the year was issued in parts of South Korea today. How do we expect the heat to affect COVID-19?

With days to only get warmer in the weeks and months to come, South Korea introduced the sales of a a new type of face masks designed to be more breathable than the N95 or KF94 respirators while shielding the wearer from respiratory droplets.
How much protection do these 'breathable' masks provide? It had been advised up until now here in South Korea to wear KF80 or KF94 masks.

Though not without unrest, the last group of students in South Korea returned to schools today in the final round of the government's four-phased reopening plan.
That doesn't mean, of course, all of the nation's 5-point 9 million grades K to 12 are back with their regular curriculum at school. The pandemic is obviously impacting school learning for students not only in this country but around the world and will continue to do so for some time.
How do pandemic of such scale impact learning for kids and what needs to be done to ensure children's education in times of pandemic?

Meanwhile, New Zealand announced today that there are no known novel coronavirus cases in the island nation for the first time since COVID-19 arrived there on February 28th.
From midnight tonight, New Zealand will move to alert level one one - and a return to mostly normal lives.
Joining us live from New Zealand is Professor John Fraser, Dean of Medical and Health Sciences at the University of Auckland.
Dean Fraser, thanks for joining us.

Before New Zealand went on strict nationwide lockdown, when the number of new COVID-19 cases were soaring, what were your first reactions to COVID-19?

As a medical expert, to which measures do you give most credit in bringing down COVID-19 cases to zero in New Zealand today? And, for your low fatality rate?

Still, the latest relaxation of restrictions does not lift border controls to New Zealand. From a medic's perspective, when is a good time for New Zealand to open up borders?

What can we do to prevent a second wave of the pandemic?

Dean John Fraser of the Faculty of Medical and Health Sciences at the University of Auckland, thank you for speaking with us. We appreciate it.

Finally, we're heading towards mid-June which means our families living overseas may start to visit us for the summer. What's the current set of guidelines for a family of four, for instance, to be visiting South Korea at the moment?

Dr. Alice Tan, as always thanks so much for your expertise and insights this evening. We appreciate it.
Reporter : jenmoon@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
S. Korea Completes Final Phase of School Re-opening as New Zealand Moves to Alert One with Zero COVID-19 Cases
Updated: 2020-06-08 15:53:15 KST

contents.context:
The protests against racism and police brutality that began in the U.S. are spreading around the globe.
Hundreds of thousands of people gathered at protests around Europe at the weekend to rally against racist violence.

"We need to bring it domestically, we need to remember that the UK is not innocent, everything you see around you is built off the backs of black and brown bodies."

At a protest in Bristol, people tore down a statue of slave trader Edward Colston and threw it into Bristol Harbour.
Amid reports of several injuries to police officers in the UK protests, Prime Minister Boris Johnson said that while people have the right to protest, they have no right to attack the police, tweeting "These demonstrations have been subverted by thuggery - and they are a betrayal of the cause they purport to serve. Those responsible will be held to account."

Over in Madrid, some three thousand protesters observed a minute of silence for Floyd and chanted 'I can't breathe.'
Demonstrators also gathered in Liberty Square in Budapest on Sunday and knelt in silence for eight minutes and 46 seconds the length of time Floyd was lying on the ground with a police officer's knee pressed down on his neck.

"It is really sad what is happening in America and I am glad that we are all taking a stand all over the world because enough is enough."

15-thousand protesters gathered at Berlin's Alexander Square.
And in Rome, people filled the Piazza del Popolo square, calling for justice for George Floyd.
Jang Tae-hyun, Arirang News
Reporter : tommyjang@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Anti-racism protests spread from U.S. to Europe
Updated: 2020-06-08 10:03:27 KST

contents.context:
U.S. President Donald Trump ordered National Guard troops to withdraw from Washington D.C. on Sunday morning, saying "everything is under perfect control", after a week and a half of protests.
The move comes as D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser formally requested last Thursday that President Trump remove the National Guard troops and other military personnel from the city.
Around 5-thousand National Guard troops and airmen from 11 states have supported the D.C. National Guard in response to the ongoing protests.
Washington D.C. saw its largest number of protesters on Saturday, with no arrests made for the third consecutive days.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Trump orders National Guard troops be withdrawn from Washington D.C.
Updated: 2020-06-08 10:02:10 KST

contents.context:
Protests that started in the U.S. crossed the Atlantic to Europe over the weekend, with people assembling in major cities chanting against racism and demanding justice for George Floyd.
Thousands of citizens took to streets in front of U.S. embassies in cities such as Berlin, London and Copenhagen echoing chants of 'I can't breathe' and they knelt in silence for eight minutes and 46 seconds the amount of time the police officer knelt on George Floyd's neck before he died.
Most of the protests were peaceful, but there were some clashes.
Fourteen police officers were hurt in London and 93 protestors were arrested in Berlin on Saturday for throwing stones and bottles.

Reporter : reina5467@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Protests against racism swell across Europe, asking justice for George Floyd
Updated: 2020-06-08 06:57:20 KST

contents.context:
OPEC and its allies have agreed to extend their oil production cuts through July, hoping to provide some stability to the market.
These are cuts of 9.7 million barrels a day, their biggest ever.
OPEC and its allies met Saturday by video conference, the only dissenter from the agreement being Mexico.
Other countries that had so far not complied with the cuts said they were now on board and would make additional cuts to compensate for their excess production in May and June.
Iraq was one that said it would comply.
Last week, the U.S. benchmark West Texas crude rose to 39 dollars a barrel.
Reporter : devin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
OPEC and its allies extend cuts of 9.7 mil. barrels/day through July
Updated: 2020-06-07 12:10:35 KST

contents.context:
A second memorial service was held on Saturday in North Carolina to honor George Floyd, the black man whose death at the hands of police last month has sparked protests around the world.
Local authorities estimated more than 30-thousand people went to Floyd's hometown of Raeford, where his body arrived.
And as demonstrations continued over the weekend in Washington D.C., the protective fence around the White House was extended to a length of almost three kilometers.
In Minneapolis, where Floyd was killed, the city council on Friday agreed to ban the use of chokeholds by police and required officers to report and intervene when they see unauthorized use of force by another officer.
Those measures still need to be approved, however, by a judge.
Reporter : kelee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Memorial service held for George Floyd in North Carolina amid looming protests
Updated: 2020-06-07 12:10:34 KST

contents.context:
The total number of cases worldwide of the coronavirus have topped 7 million as of Saturday, according to a tally by Reuters, as numbers surge in Brazil and India.
The number of deaths is approaching 400-thousand.
Almost a third of the cases worldwide are in the United States, as are about a fourth of the fatalities.
Deaths are rapidly rising in Brazil, which could overtake the UK as the country with the second-highest death toll.
Although the real numbers are believed to be higher, the number of fatalities linked to COVID-19 is now equal to the number of people who die annually from malaria, one of the world's most deadly infectious diseases.
Reporter : devin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Global COVID-19 cases top 7 million; deaths approaching 400,000: Reuters
Updated: 2020-06-07 12:10:34 KST

contents.context:
Former U.S. Vice President Joe Biden has now won enough delegates to become the official Democratic presidential candidate for the upcoming presidential race.
The result came late Friday, local time, after seven states and the District of Columbia held presidential primaries earlier this week.
Reaching the threshold number of delegates was a formality as his competitors, including Bernie Sanders, had dropped out of the race.
Throughout his political career as a senator, he has run for the candidacy twice.
During this current campaign, he promised to choose a woman for his running mate with several women of color thought to be on the short-list.
Reporter : tkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Biden becomes official Democratic candidate for 2020 Presidential Election
Updated: 2020-06-06 15:50:51 KST

contents.context:
U.S President Donald Trump touted the surprise rise in the employment rate amid the ongoing Black Lives Matter protests and COVID-19 pandemic.
Despite experts' forecast on the economy, it was reported that the country added a surprising 2.5 million jobs in May.
The U.S. President then pleaded with states to re-open their economies while claiming the recovery is better than a "V" shape labeling it instead as a "rocket ship".
In addition, he mentioned that a strong economy is the best response to racial tensions adding he hopes the late victim of police brutality, George Floyd, is looking down from heaven saying it's a "great thing that's happening for our country."
Reporter : tkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Trump hails rise in employment rate, calling it a "rocket ship" recovery
Updated: 2020-06-06 13:01:45 KST

contents.context:
South Korea has pledged assistance worth 30 million U.S. dollars for five years starting next year to fund the supply of vaccines of various kinds for the world's poorest countries.
Foreign Minister Kang Kyung-wha took part in the Global Vaccine Summit 2020 hosted online by British Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Thursday.
The meeting, held to raise funds for 'Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance' for the 2021 to 2025 period brought together leaders from more than 30 countries who pledged more than 8.8 billion dollars in total to develop and distribute vaccines for diseases such as measles and polio.
The biggest pledge to Gavi came from the UK at two billion dollars.
Reporter : jhlucyoh@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea pledges assistance of US$ 30 mil. for global vaccine drive
Updated: 2020-06-05 17:25:19 KST
